name: N,N'-(ethane-1,2-diyldibenzene-2,1-diyl)diacetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3063

name: N,N'-(ethane-1,2-diyldibenzene-2,1-diyl)diacetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3063
Reason: The basic structure for the target compound can be considered as two benzene rings, which are part of acetanilide when considering the melting point. The basic acetanilide has a melting point near 114°C. Each benzene ring provides aromatic stability and a planar structure which can lead to pi-pi stacking interactions, contributing to a higher melting point. The ethane linker introduces some flexibility but also contributes to molecular size which can increase the melting point. The additional amide groups form strong hydrogen bonds, which significantly increase the melting point due to the need for more energy to break these interactions. Considering the effects, each benzene ring adds approximately +30°C due to pi-stacking; each amide group for hydrogen bonding contributes +50°C. Adding these adjustments from the base structure of acetanilide (114°C for the benzene plus the amide component): 114 (acetanilide base) + 30 (additional benzene ring) + 100 (two additional amide groups for robust hydrogen bonding) = 244°C
